mdRecord.dcterms:title: Emmanuel Episcopal Church, interior
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Cram, Goodhue and Ferguson (American architectural firm, 1898-1913) [work]
Wilson, Richard Guy [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Emmanuel Episcopal Church was established in 1841 as a mission of Newport's Trinity Church. In 1852, the congregation was admitted into Diocesan Convention as Emmanuel Free Church. In 1901, Natalie Bayard Brown decided to build a new church on the site to honor her late husband, John Nicholas Brown, Sr. The first service was held in 1902. The two bells in the tower, cast by the same English foundry that made Philadelphia’s Liberty Bell, were given in 1903 by Natalie’s mother-in-law, Sophia Augusta Brown, in memory of her son Harold. The reredos and wall murals were given in 1921 by Natalie Brown as a peace memorial for Armistice Day. The stained glass windows were made by Harry Eldredge Goodhue, born in 1873 and known as one of three stained glass craftsmen to revive the art and craft of medieval glass-making during the last decade of the 19th Century and the first decade of the 20th. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmanuel_Church_%28Newport,_Rhode_Island%29 [work]
mdRecord.dcterms:subject: Architecture and City Planning
religious buildings
